before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"8o0k","text":"When conducting sample selection, it is crucial to choose healthy plants, avoiding those displaying signs of disease or stress, as such conditions can potentially compromise the quality of mycorrhizal associations. Additionally, consider the timing of tissue collection, selecting a stage of plant growth that aligns with your research objectives, as different stages may exhibit varying levels of mycorrhizal colonization. During root sampling, exercise caution to prevent damage to mycorrhizal structures. Gently dig around the plant to expose the root system, employing a shovel or hand trowel to carefully lift the roots from the soil. Following this, ensure thorough root washing by rinsing them gently with water, eliminating excess soil and debris. Use a fine-mesh sieve or a gentle stream of water to prevent any potential damage to the mycorrhizal structures.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

description: {"blocks":[{"key":"1t6im","text":"This protocol outlines a rapid staining technique for visualizing Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi (AMF) colonization in legume roots. Careful sample selection is emphasized, avoiding stressed or diseased plants that may compromise mycorrhizal associations. Root sampling involves gentle extraction to prevent damage to mycorrhizal structures. The FAA fixative is recommended for preserving roots before staining. Following fixation, a meticulous staining process involves successive treatments with KOH, HCl, Trypan Blue stain, and an acetic acid:glycerol:distilled water solution. Stained roots, mounted on microscopic slides with 30% glycerol, are examined under a light microscope. The protocol provides detailed steps, from sample collection to microscopic observation, allowing researchers to efficiently visualize and document fungal structures, including extra-radicle hyphae, intra-radicle structures, vesicles, and arbuscules. This technique facilitates accurate assessment of mycorrhizal colonization in legume roots, contributing to a better understanding of plant-fungal symbiotic interactions.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"2ebsf","text":"If you're not proceeding with staining immediately, the FAA fixative is used for preserving root samples prior to mycorrhizal staining. Here's a brief protocol for using FAA fixative before mycorrhizal staining:","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7v1a5","text":"Prepare FAA Fixative:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1e3dt","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fi7pc","text":"Mix formaldehyde, acetic acid, and ethanol in a 1 : 1 : 18 ratio, respectively, to create the FAA fixative solution.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"22hmr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cf87u","text":"Store in FAA Fixative:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":22}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"abd6b","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7eoed","text":"Submerge the cleaned roots in the FAA fixative solution. Roots can be stored for up to 4 weeks at 4 °C.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"avbmv","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"68i10","text":"Before proceeding with the staining process, thoroughly rinse the sample 5 times with deionized water for one minute each time to eliminate any residual traces of FAA. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bmc33","text":"Add a freshly prepared 5% (w/v) KOH solution to each tube, ensuring complete coverage of the root sample, and incubate at a temperature of 89±1°C for a duration of one hour.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4av6s","text":"","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4iv6","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3an8i","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"37hvc","text":"In the case of field-grown roots, immerse them in a 5% KOH solution and let them soak overnight at 40°C. Observe the KOH turning yellow overnight, signifying the removal of tannins from the tissue into the solution. This step can be performed either before or after the heat treatment process.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cjr4i","text":"Next, thoroughly rinse the root samples with tap water three times. Then add a 5% HCl solution, allowing it to sit for approximately 3 minutes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"472iu","text":"Preparation of a 0.05% Trypan Blue stain:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":41}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dpdog","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5ck7d","text":"33 ml Lactic Acid\n33 ml Glycero ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a1qne","text":"33 ml Distilled water\n0.5 g Trypan Blue","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4ooq0","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ates7","text":"Heat the 0.05% Trypan Blue stain to 89 ± 1°C. Remove the HCl solution and replace it with the heated stain. Maintain incubation at 89 ± 1°C for 15 minutes.","type":"align-justify","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6t5a2","text":"Replace the stain with a freshly prepared solution of ´acetic acid:glycerol:distilled water (1:1:1)´ and allow the roots to soak at 40°C for 15 minutes. Repeat this procedure three times consecutively.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4fre","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"779ff","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"abfel","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"1t1f4","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fiu66","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1g7c1","text":"Roots can be preserved in 30% glycerol at 4°C until they are ready for MICROSCOPIC examination.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5g5ef","text":"If the roots exhibit a deep blue color, it indicates that they were not adequately cleared during the 5% KOH process, signaling the need for additional optimization.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6mmv2","text":"Stained roots measuring 1-5 cm are affixed to a microscopic slide using 30% glycerol. Initially, the roots are examined under a light microscope and documented. Subsequently, the tissues are gently smashed and dispersed, facilitating the observation and documentation of fungal structures, including extra-radicle hyphae (Figure 1), intra-radicle structures (Figure 2), vesicles (Figure 3), and arbuscules (Figure 4).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
